abstract: Now that Republicans have taken over the House, they’re itching to tamp down the new financial services regulations passed by Congress this summer.

title: Competition's Shortcomings in Curtailing Health Care Costs
abstract: The notion that increasing competition among insurers in a given market will drive down the cost of premiums is not borne out in practice, an economist writes.

title: Does Competition Benefit Health Insurance Subscribers?
abstract: Whether more competition creates better health-insurances choices in a local market is not so simple to establish, an economist writes.

title: Treasury Links Foreclosure Ills to Lower Housing Prices
abstract: The uncertainty over the legal status of foreclosed homes could further delay the recovery of the housing market, the Obama administration said.

title: Health Care Accounting Is Challenging, Not Impossible
abstract: If financial accountants can provide earnings estimate regarded as reliable, an economist asks, why can’t health-care accountants do the same?

title: U.S. Tries to Ease Wider Worries Over Foreclosures
abstract: The housing secretary said that the government had yet to find evidence of widespread problems in the foreclosure process, but that the investigations would continue.

title: White House Urges Calm on Foreclosures
abstract: “A national, blanket moratorium on all foreclosure sales would do far more harm than good,” one administration member said on Sunday.

title: White House Urges Calm on Lenders
abstract: Amid a rising uproar over slipshod bank foreclosure practices, members of the Obama administration on Sunday expressed anger about the revelations, but urged caution as multiple investigations into the crisis unfold.

title: A Foreclosure Tightrope for Democrats
abstract: Outcry over foreclosures has thrust the Obama administration back into the position of sheltering the banking industry from an angry public’s demands.

title: Actelion Is Said to Explore Potential Sale
abstract: Actelion, a Swiss biotech drug maker, has formed a special board committee to explore a potential sale of the company, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing unnamed sources.

title: The Battle for Stuyvesant Town
abstract: The fate of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village rests on the interpretation of one clause in a legal agreement, the Deal Professor says.

title: Dell and Its Deadline
abstract: The deadline for Dell to respond to Hewlett-Packard's offer for 3Par is only hours a way. The Deal Professor expects Dell to try to slow down the bidding war.

title: 2 New Federal Programs to Help Borrowers Pay Their Mortgages
abstract: The F.H.A. will begin a refinancing effort to help borrowers who are struggling and will start an emergency homeowners’ loan program for unemployed borrowers.

title: With Squeeze on Credit, Microlending Blossoms
abstract: After banks refused loan requests, some small businesses in the United States turned to microloans like those offered in the third world.

title: How I Saved My Company: Darn Tough Vermont
abstract: When manufacturing work started going overseas in search of low-cost labor, business fell off sharply.

title: Should You Trust Mint.com?
abstract: After hearing the news that the personal finance management service Wesabe is shutting down, we asked experts whether consumers should trust rival sites like Mint.com with their financial account information.

title: Reporting on Police Torture Brings Verdict, but Who Will Do the Work Next Time Around?
abstract: A long-running story on police torture in Chicago yields a verdict, but John Conroy, the reporter whose work got the investigation started, no longer has a job.

title: Steve Jobs: Strong, Not-So-Silent Type
abstract: A drink next to the keyboard begets a conversation with Steve Jobs.

title: Introducing She Owns It: 'I Didn't Know There Were Women Out There Like Me'
abstract: The constant focus on fast-growth firms can obscure the contributions of female entrepreneurs. This blog intends to share their stories and start a conversation.

title: Packing Tips From Travel Pros
abstract: As new airline baggage fees prompt travelers to pack lighter, packing efficiently becomes even more important.

title: United and Continental Announce Merger
abstract: United Airlines and Continental Airlines on Monday announced a $3 billion merger that would create the world's biggest airline.

title: Obama Looks to Close Sale on Financial Reform
abstract: Well before the financial system nearly collapsed in September 2008, Barack Obama, more than any other presidential candidate, was warning about holes in the regulatory fabric and crises on the horizon. Soon he'll be making his closing arguments to push the overhaul through.

title: A New PETA Ad Will Feature the Late Bea Arthur
abstract: A new ad for the People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals features Bea Arthur, the star of TV series like "Maude" and "The Golden Girls," who died last April. Ms. Arthur was a staunch supporter of PETA's initiatives against so-called factory farming techniques.

title: O’Brien Will Move to TBS
abstract: Conan O’Brien, who had been expected to sign a deal with Fox, has agreed to join TBS’s late-night lineup after negotiations that began just days ago.

title: Funding Budding Researchers With a Click of the Mouse
abstract: With a scarcity of funding for small-scale research projects, a handful of new nonprofit organizations have jumped into the fray, created to give the public an opportunity to pay for scientific research that is not fully supported by government or private sources.

title: Greenberg on Two Years After Bear's Fall
abstract: On the two-year anniversary of JPMorgan Chase’s agreement to buy Bear Stearns, Alan C. Greenberg told Bloomberg Television about life after the 85-year-old investment bank’s near-collapse.

title: A Must Read for Anyone Who Wants to Sell a Business
abstract: There are universal lessons in Norm Brodsky's "The Offer" series that can be applied to deals of all sizes.

title: HBO Go, the Best Online Video Service I Cannot Use
abstract: The service ignores the viewing habits of some Web-only video viewers.

title: HBO Prepares Site That Will Offer Shows and Movies
abstract: A site called HBO Go promises access to shows and films.

title: At Ad Council Dinner, Tart Humor From Tina Fey
abstract: The "30 Rock" actress poked fun of the heads of NBC Universal and General Electric, as well as her look-alike, Sarah Palin.

title: How the N.F.I.B. Represents Its Members, Part II
abstract: Why is membership in the organization declining and what does this say about its lobbying efforts?

title: For Mozilla and Google, Group Hugs Get Tricky
abstract: Mozilla’s open-source Firefox browser now faces competition from a gigantic longtime partner.

title: From Treasury to Banks, an Ultimatum on Mortgage Relief
abstract: The federal government is taking the largest mortgage servicers to the woodshed on their efforts to modify shaky loans.

title: At Beazer Homes, It Was See No Evil and Pay No Penalty
abstract: Beazer Homes USA, a home builder, settled its legal crimes, but its top officials remain with the company.

title: MSNBC Expands Its Liberal Lineup
abstract: Ed Schultz, a radio veteran who appeals to Democrats, will anchor the 6 p.m. hour starting Monday.

title: Who's Who at Gadgetwise
abstract: The New York Times Gadgetwise blog provides advice on electronics, gadgets and other personal-tech products.

title: Amid Conference Halls and Keynote Speakers, a Rivalry Forms
abstract: Michael Arrington, founder the TechCrunch blog the co-organizer of TechCrunch50, a technology conference, has incited a bitter public dispute with a more established competitor, Demo, over the most ethical way to run such a conference.

title: JPMorgan's Expanding Footprint
abstract: DealBook maps out JPMorgan's footprint in the wake of the Bear Stearns deal.

title: They're Working on Their Own, Just Side by Side
abstract: Equipped with cellphones and Wi-Fi, young people who work independently are banding together in shared spaces.

title: Flickr Users Consider Their Potential Microsoft Overlords
abstract: Microsoft's bid is shaking up the community of the photo-sharing site Flickr, which is owned by Yahoo.

title: A Few More Questions
abstract: More unanswered questions to ponder over the holidays. Add your own.

title: Questions We Thought, But Didn’t Ask, in 2007
abstract: As the year ends, we ask the questions that perplex us the most.

title: A Big Bet on Kayak for Travel Search
abstract: Mike Moritz of Sequoia Capital and some other prominent venture capitalists are making a big bet on Kayak, the travel search engine, to challenge Expedia and the other online travel agencies.

title: Microsoft’s Arguments Against Google-DoubleClick Marriage
Who Is Really Hurt by Apple Rumor Site’s Closure?
abstract: Apple settled its suit against Think Secret and the site agreed to close. Lawyers say Apple likely made a substantial payment to ThinkSecret’s founder, Nick Ciarelli, who says other bloggers should be emboldened.

title: Is Information Overload a $650 Billion Drag on the Economy?
abstract: A business research firm tries to estimate the “cost of unnecessary interruptions” in terms of lost productivity and innovation.

title: Rabbit-Ear Users Don’t Know The End (of Analog TV) Is Near
abstract: Half the people in a recent survey don’t know that analog over-the-air television will be cut off in 2009. And of the 17 percent of households that don’t have cable or satellite service, only one-third know their televisions will stop receiving broadcast signals.

title: Google: There’s Nobody in Our Black Box. Yet.
abstract: Google uses a global network of part-time quality raters to help it evaluate proposed changes to its search formulas. But those people don’t directly affect the search results, as Bits wrote Tuesday.

title: Paul Allen and Echostar Line Up for Spectrum Auction
abstract: We don’t know everyone who is bidding in the 700-megahertz spectrum auction, but Paul Allen and Echostar have signed up to bid against Google, AT&T and Verizon.

title: The Web Is Overrun With Elves
abstract: OfficeMax has a holiday hit on its hands once again with ElfYourself.com.

title: Viacom Dumps DoubleClick for Microsoft
abstract: Microsoft and Viacom team up on ads and content, and Google quickly points to the deal as evidence that the online ad market is plenty competitive.

title: The People Inside Google’s Black Box
abstract: A top Google scientist confirms what has been rumored for years: the company improves its search engine by asking thousands of part-time workers to rate Web sites.

title: Object-Oriented Objects at N.Y.U.
abstract: Wool gizmos that show you around the city, pillows that help you have lucid dreams, and sidewalks with sensors were among the 100 projects on display at the year-end show at New York University’s Interactive Telecommunications Program.

title: The Depth of eBay’s Problems 2: Angry Sellers
abstract: Sellers are defecting from eBay because its fees are high, customers are afraid of fraud, and merchants can do better on Amazon or on their own Web sites, attracting customers through Google.

title: Beyond Sheep-Throwing: Rhapsody on Facebook
abstract: The new Facebook application for the Rhapsody music service shows some of the advantages of integrating powerful applications into Facebook’s environment.

title: Would You Buy a Telephone From a Company Named Ribbit?
abstract: A startup takes an entire telephone company switchboard and makes it available over the Internet. This allows programmers to develop applications that combine telephone calls and other data.

title: The Depth of eBay’s Problems 1: Disappointed Buyers
abstract: After a post suggesting that Amazon buy eBay, Bits readers revolt with a litany of complaints about eBay. The site, they say, has such bad customer service and is so riddled with fraud that Amazon should stay away.

title: Why Amazon Should Buy eBay
abstract: Now that Amazon’s market value is nearly the same as eBay’s, it could buy the online auction site. That could help improve Amazon’s finances and eBay’s customer satisfaction.

title: Gotta Find a Wii
abstract: GameStop is going to offer rain checks for Wiis to its customers.

title: Why Amazon Should Buy eBay
abstract: Now that Amazon’s market value is nearly the same as eBay’s, it could buy the online auction site. That could help improve Amazon’s finances and eBay’s customer satisfaction.

title: Google’s Advertising Black Box Becomes Just a Bit Translucent
abstract: In a move to open its closed advertising system, Google will now let Website owners who sell advertising through Google’s AdSense system to review and reject advertisements they don’t find appropriate.

title: Wrong Number From Sprint
abstract: Sprint is canceling some fees it charges to cover its own costs and replacing them with other “regulatory” and “administrative” fees. As with similar fees at other carriers, the money goes to Sprint, not the government, and raises the question whether this is the right way for companies to advertise prices.

title: Samsung Thrives Amid L.C.D. Shortages
abstract: A shortage of large panels is boosting margins for Samsung Semiconductor, the largest maker of L.C.D. displays. Scott Birnbaum, Samsung’s top L.C.D. sales executive for the Americas, sees displays with even greater resolution than the current high definition sets.

title: Not Everyone Thinks Tech Spending Will Slow
abstract: The big research houses have been trimming their forecasts for global technology spending, but one forecaster thinks foreign spending will make up for a domestic slowdown, and I.B.M. is stepping up its push into developing markets.

title: Fear at the Fed
abstract: The combined actions of the world’s central banks smack of a real fear that the world’s financial system is in trouble.

title: Cheatsheet: Online Ad Spending to Slow
abstract: By 2011, eMarketer predicts, $42 billion will be spent in advertising online. That will only be a 12 percent increase from 2010, compared to a growth rate next year of 29 percent. Social networks won’t get much of that money, but video sites and mobile phones will.

title: Bebo Copies Facebook, Which Invites Others to Do the Same
abstract: Bebo has developed a system to let applications written for Facebook run on its social network. Facebook then decided to let other networks do the same. All this is meant to fight off the Google-MySpace environment called OpenSocial.

title: Privacy Groups Question F.T.C. Chairwoman’s DoubleClick Ties
abstract: Two privacy groups asked the chairwoman of the Federal Trade Commission to recuse herself from the commission’s review of Google’s merger with DoubleClick. The chairwoman’s husband works at a law firm representing DoubleClick.

title: As Ask Erases Little, Google and Others Keep Writing About You
abstract: While Ask.com is trying to score marketing points by offering not to collect data about users, the real privacy issues are raised by Google — which doesn’t use much user data yet — and by Yahoo, AOL and others, which are tracking users in order to show them advertising targeted to their interests.

title: Make Your Own Ringtones (Even With Copyrighted Songs)
abstract: Cellware is a new site that is a sort of YouTube for ringtones. It makes it easy for people to send ringtones from any MP3 file to their phone without a charge.

title: The First Orders Arrive for Chocolate Beta Bars
abstract: It’s an auspicious start for Mr. Rossetto and his business partner, Timothy Childs, who have set up their business in an old warehouse on the San Francisco waterhouse. They say they’re proud to be bringing a chocolate factory back to San Francisco, a city known for chocolate but currently without a manufacturer in town.

title: When Big Blue Got a Glimpse of the Future
abstract: Theodore Holm Nelson paid a visit to I.B.M. in 1978 that left quite an impression on executives who were developing that company’s first personal computer.

title: Bill Me Later Is Getting Big Now
abstract: Amazon.com has agreed to accept Bill Me Later, an alternative credit card system, which has grown rapidly in recent years.

title: Universal’s Imeem Deal May Unlock More Free Music
abstract: With the addition of Universal Music Group, Imeem, a social network, can now let users listen to nearly any song they want on their computers. This may be the breakthrough the music industry needs: Streaming songs will be free with advertising, but downloading to keep will require payment.

title: What Should Apple Do With its Piggy Bank?
abstract: Apple has put an additional $5 billion in the bank over the last year, giving it more cash than any company other than Microsoft and Cisco. Should it make acquisitions, pay a dividend, buy its stock back, or just look at the money pile up in the vault?

title: Is Macrovision Bringing More Cops to Your Living Room?
abstract: Macrovision hopes that buying TV Guide will let it merge copy protection systems into electronic program guides making it harder to use electronic devices without Hollywood looking over your shoulder.

title: More on WD’s Hard Drive That Won’t Share Video
abstract: A Western Digital hard drive blocks people from sharing video and music files over the Internet, but it doesn’t keep them from storing them or sharing them within their homes or offices, as some reports have suggested.

title: Facebook Members Sell Their Own Ads
abstract: There is a way to place your own advertising on Facebook. The question is, will Facebook allow it?

title: Fixing Guitar Hero III’s Mono Problem
abstract: Activision says it plans to offer replacement discs to fix a glitch in the Wii version of Guitar Hero III.

title: The Blessed Second Life of Beliefnet
abstract: After Beliefnet filed for bankruptcy protection in 2002, the founders and employees of the site had their stock holdings wiped out. But they paid themselves in stock as they rebuilt the company, and ended up owning one-third of the shares that were sold this week to the News Corporation.

title: Entrepreneurial Journalism in the Facebook Age
abstract: A competition among journalism students for seed money shows that Web services like AdSense, Facebook and Ning may make it much easier to start a publication than ever before.

title: Rudolph Shows the Way for CBS
abstract: The Christmas classic "Rudolph the Red-Nosed Reindeer" led CBS to a Tuesday night victory in the ratings as the special delivered 14.4 million viewers at 8 p.m., according to Nielsen's estimates.

title: Zuckerberg Apologizes, Allows Facebook Users to Evade Beacon
abstract: In a contrite blog post, Mark Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, says his company has mishandled its Beacon system, which tells people’s friends about what they bought on line. The company has added a way to opt out.

title: As Tech Buying Slows, G.P.S. Stays the Course
abstract: Consumer electronics sales over the week of Thanksgiving increased by just 6 percent, half the increase of last year. The bright spot was G.P.S. navigation units and digital picture frames.

title: We’ll Give You Millions — If You Can Get Through Gladys
abstract: CAA, the talent agency, wants to be a venture capital firm, too. But how exactly is an entrepreneur going to get through the receptionist?

title: Nokia and Universal’s Proposed Music Tax
abstract: The “Comes With Music” program just announced by Nokia, under which some cellphones will be bundled with the right to download an unlimited number of songs for a year, offers an interesting model for the music business.

title: Hacking Rings Take Advantage of Death in Boston
The March of the iPhone Clones
abstract: Verizon’s new $49 Voyager phone is one of the first of the iPhone clones. How good is it?

title: A Year Later: Chat on AIM through GMail
abstract: Gmail users can now have instant-message conversations with users of AOL’s AIM system, fulfilling a key term of the deal in which Google invested $1 billion in AOL. The message services of Yahoo and MSN are linked to each other but not to Google or AOL.

title: The Spectrum Auction Secrecy Begins
abstract: At least four major companies are thought to have filed today to bid in the coming auction for wireless spectrum. But F.C.C. rules prevent any of them from talking about it.

title: Yahoo Shuffles Yet More Executives
abstract: Yahoo has consolidated its media unit under Scott Moore, who had run the news, sports and finance half of its operation in Santa Monica. Vince Brody, who ran the other half, devoted entertainment, is looking for a new role in the company.

title: DVD Movies With an iTunes Copy: Worth More?
abstract: Question of the day: Reports say Apple is negotiating to get more studios to sell movie downloads through iTunes. One reason is that they want to sell DVDs with extra copies that can be moved onto iPods. Would you pay $3 extra for this?

title: Coke Is Holding Off on Sipping Facebook’s Beacon
abstract: After the uproar over Facebook’s system to spread information about its users’ online purchases to their friends, Coca-Cola, a major advertiser, is shelving plans to use the system for now.

title: Facebook: What Would Google Do?
abstract: As Facebook reaches for more investors and pushes hard (then backs off) on its advertising plans, it may want to look at the equally ambitious, but slower paced, style of Google.

title: Is the Exaflood Coming?
abstract: A new study says we may be facing an “exaflood” of higher demand for broadbaand. The telecom industry is behind the study, which doesn’t mean it is wrong. But a prominent researcher who called the telecom bubble in 1998 says it isn’t as bad as some people want you to think it will be.

title: Facebook Executive Discusses Beacon Brouhaha
abstract: A Facebook vice president addresses the company’s privacy dustup, and outlines a few changes to its controversial Beacon program.

title: Nano’s Rear-View Mirror
abstract: Plastic-producing bacteria? How ’70s. But nanotech, and rising oil prices, is bringing new life to an old idea.

title: The Back of Henry Blodget’s Envelope
abstract: Microsoft’s MSN division is worth $10 billion, Henry Blodget calculates. That’s not enough to trade for much of Yahoo, but giving up control may be the best bet for Microsoft.

title: One More Beacon Amendment From Facebook
abstract: Facebook makes yet another change to its controversial Beacon program.

title: One More Beacon Amendment From Facebook
abstract: Facebook makes yet another change to its controversial Beacon program.

title: Verizon’s Real Move to Openness
abstract: Verizon Wireless said today it will use a technical standard known as LTE for its next generation network. Since that standard is being adopted by most of the world, and by AT&T in the United States, Verizon’s move will spur competition and give customers more choices for phones.

title: Google Doesn’t Know Where You Are (But It Has a Good Guess)
abstract: A new feature to Google’s cellphone mapping service can figure out more or less sort of where you are. It’s got some slick technology to help it figure that out.

title: Don’t Give Up on Leopard (Despite the Bugs)
abstract: Even as Apple mocks the problems of Windows Vista, its own OS X Leopard is causing system crashes and other problems.

title: Verizon Wireless Says ‘Bring Your Own’ Device
abstract: Verizon Wireless will allow any device and any application to run on its network next year. This will help increase volume and strengthen its hand in bidding for more bandwidth.

title: Microsoft’s Windows Live Yahoo Hotmail Problem
abstract: Why the numbers and the strategy simply don’t work for Microsoft to combine with Yahoo.

title: MySpace Isn’t Just for People Who Like to Watch
abstract: Peter Levinsohn, the head of Fox Interactive Media, said that MySpace is more for entertainment and Facebook for communications. He forgets that MySpace’s appeal is that users communicate with each other through their selection of music, video and photos.

title: The Other Half of Open: Competition
abstract: As AOL learned with its failed attempt to offer broadband service, open access to networks doesn’t help if the price is too high and the terms too tough.

title: Walking Off Into the Vista
abstract: Sure, Vista is annoying. But even more annoying is Microsoft’s word processing software. And that’s one more compelling reason for a move to cloud computing.

title: Google Checkout and PayPal Spend Big to Lure Buyers
abstract: Google Checkout and eBay’s PayPal generous promotions today to increase their share of holiday spending. But when they don’t buy friends, merchants say neither has much appeal at major online stores.

title: Yahoo’s Cyber Monday Meltdown
abstract: Outages in Yahoo’s service for small online retailers lead to frustration and a disappointing Cyber Monday for some Web sites.

title: A Little Attack Ad for Apple
abstract: Apple’s attack ad on Microsft’s Vista retains the bemused attachment of the already-classic campaign.

title: A Different Kind of Networking
abstract: Remember when people used to meet in the street, face to face?

title: Web Research Drives More Real-World Purchases
abstract: Amid the generally lackluster holiday season, the percentage of offline purchases that are researched online is booming.

title: Turning Nonworking Gizmos Into Money
abstract: An entrepreneur builds a business around buying broken iPods and iPhones.

title: A Thanksgiving Blessing
abstract: Happy Thanksgiving. Now put down those Blackberries.

title: Cellphones Get Cheaper, So People Pay More
abstract: The average spent on a cellphone in the United States was $82.81 in the third quarter, up from $58.95 a year ago. The extra money is buying features like built in MP3 players and smartphone capabilities.

title: In Defense of the Kindle
abstract: Many people are criticizing Amazon’s Kindle for being too expensive and leaving out features. But doubtless Amazon will cut the price and add features over time. What Amazon has got right is the simplicity of finding, buying and reading books on the Kindle.

title: Vizio Stays on Top in L.C.D. TVs
abstract: In the third quarter, Vizio, a low-priced TV brand, kept the No. 1 spot in the L.C.D television market. But Samsung, Sharp and Sony all gained share at the expense of second-tier brands.

title: Electronic Books: If It Ain’t Broke . . .
abstract: At $400, the Kindle seems expensive. But there is one sector for which it would be fully amortized in a matter of months — college students.

title: Amazon Pitches a Wireless iPod for Books
abstract: Amazon’s new Kindle reader costs $399 and can download books, newspapers and blog posts wirelessly.

title: Enough About Kindle 1.0. What About Kindle 2.0?
abstract: Potential future features that Jeff Bezos may add to his new e-book device, the Amazon Kindle.

title: J Allard: Microsoft’s Plan to Be King of All Media
abstract: Microsoft is building an online service that will be the back end for all sorts of communication and entertainment, linking XBox games, Zune music, video and cellphones.

title: J Allard: The Failures of the Zune and the Record Labels
abstract: The first generation of the Zune achieved its goal of “failing fast,” says J Allard, who is in charge of the product at Microsoft. It wasn’t helped, he said, by flawed business models from the record labels.

title: J Allard: Dancing Around the Cellphone Question
abstract: Microsoft hopes to respond to the iPhone with better software, but it may not make the phones itself.

title: Sony Needs a Hero for PlayStation 3
abstract: Guitar Hero joins Madden NFL and Halo as one of the top video game franchises. But an analysis of the sales numbers reveals PlayStation 3 has problems.

title: Dell on the Rebound?
abstract: Forrester, a research firm, says Dell is on the mend with its corporate customers. It also finds resistance to Windows Vista among corporations.

title: Score One for the Web’s Don Quixote
abstract: A quixotic mission to free government information took a stop closer to reality when Fastcase electronically published a free archive of federal case law.

title: Digital Actors in ‘Beowulf’ Are Just Uncanny
abstract: The makers of the computer-animated movie “Beowulf” used motion-capture technology to digitize performances by famous actors — with some not-so-pleasing results.

title: Be an Eco Sinner or Saint in the New SimCity
abstract: The latest version of SimCity Societies, which launches on Thursday, allows you to play out the global climate experiment, designing cities that either expand or limit their greenhouse-gas contribution and environmental footprint — and seeing the consequences unfold, for better or worse.

title: A Night With Chumby
abstract: The new Web-enabled Chumby alarm clock can put ads in the bedroom.

title: Inbox 2.0: Yahoo and Google to Turn E-Mail Into a Social Network
abstract: For Google, the future of social networks is not Orkut. For Yahoo, it’s not Yahoo Mash. Both are betting that e-mail and personal home pages can be extended to undercut the activity now on Facebook and MySpace.

title: The Freedom of Free
abstract: Bebo, the social network that is popular in Britain, says any producer can put video on its site and keep all of the advertising revenue. It would rather get more content, and a bigger audience, than get bogged down with deal negotiations.

title: Netflix Prize: Close, but No $1 Million Cigar
Bill Would Make Colleges Copyright Cops
abstract: An education bill under consideration in the House would cut off aid to colleges and universities that don’t actively help movie studios and record labels prevent trading in copyrighted works.

title: Glam Lets Rivals Copy Its Ad Network Plan, and Takes a Cut
abstract: Glam’s deal to run an advertising network for the Lifetime cable network is a textbook example of how to co-opt potential competition.

title: A First Look at the Google Phone
abstract: Google gives a first look at what Google Phones based on the Android software will look like. Think iPhone.

title: I.B.M. Blue Gene Still the Fastest Computer
abstract: I.B.M. retains the title as maker of the world’s fasterst computer, but more of the fastest machines are overseas.

title: Seeding the Google Phone With Apps
abstract: Google tries to lure developers for its new phone software with prize money. And why not? A similar strategy appears to be working for Facebook.

title: Is It Spelled Yahoogle or Yoogle?
abstract: Like that other search company, Yahoo is trying to build ties to researchers who can develop better ways to use huge clusters of computers.

title: Apple Notes: Finding Clues About Movie Rentals
abstract: A search of Apple’s code unleashes a fever of speculation about what is next. Could it be movie rentals through iTunes?

title: E-Mail Scammers Ask Your Friends for Money
abstract: In the latest Nigerian e-mail scam, the crooks are taking a page from Facebook and leveraging the power of social connections.

title: Cheering On the Tech Stock Crash
abstract: An argument against the hand wringing about Nasdaq’s fall. The only way to prevent the ill-effects of a tech stock bubble is for share prices to fall.

title: Apple Notes: Another iPhone Jailbreak
abstract: Apple locks the iPhone, and hackers release it. Again.

title: Barry Diller’s Bill Gates Imitation
abstract: IAC has just introduced 236.com, a fake news site. Seen that idea before? So did Barry Diller, who, like Microsoft, is trying to profit from the ideas of others.

title: Trust Among Friends on Facebook
abstract: Who wants product recommendations from the kind of people who have hundreds of friends on Facebook?

title: Are Facebook’s Social Ads Illegal?
abstract: A 100-year-old law in New York State bans the use of a person’s name and likeness for advertising purposes without permission. That may be what Facebook’s new Social Ads system does.

title: Bring This to the Next Meeting
abstract: How much money is wasted during meetings? This calculator could track it.

title: Hackers Infect Alicia Keys’s MySpace Page
abstract: Hackers have infiltrated the MySpace page of R&B singer Alicia Keys and set a dangerous trap for her fans.

title: Facebook Everywhere
abstract: Once the company gets the bugs out of its system for social ads on its own site, Facebook will likely create a network to use its data to display advertising on other sites.

title: Log Off and Get to Work
abstract: According to a new survey, more companies are blocking MySpace in the workplace than are blocking oncoming rival Facebook.

title: Darth Gore to Senator Obama: I Am Your Father
abstract: A new animated Web series mocks the presidential candidates and hopes to make it to regular television

title: The Ad Network Campaign
abstract: AOL’s Advertising.com put ads for Mitt Romney on Gay.com. How long can advertisers control their messages in a world of advertising networks and user-generated content?

title: Ad Networks Are the New Dot-Coms
abstract: Web sites of all sorts are starting their own advertising networks. Even Martha Stewart has decided that ad networks are a good thing.

title: Facebook’s Next Privacy Problem
abstract: Facebook’s plan to put pictures of your friends on ads will make you notice them more. But your friends may object to being used to shill products, and Facebook isn’t giving them a choice.

title: AOL’s New Plan: It’s Not Working
abstract: Randy Falco is betting that AOL’s advertising network will turn the company around. But ad sales are slowing and the problems will continue through next year.

title: The Bubble in Tom Perkins’s Sails
abstract: Tom Perkins, the venture capitalist, says bubbles aren’t so bad.

title: PayPal is Rude in the Lunch Line
abstract: While helping transfer money into an elementary school lunch money system, eBay’s PayPal shows that it is more interested in cutting its costs than helping users, thereby ceding some of its franchise to Google Checkout.

title: The Debate Over Cellphone Jamming
abstract: The debate over the use of cellphone jammers is vigorous.

title: Eric Schmidt’s GPhone Dance
abstract: Google said it wasn’t announcing its own cellphone model. Yet. But it did say it planned to cut deals with cellphone carriers to share cellphone advertising revenue.

title: Barry Diller and the Fallacy of IAC
abstract: Barry Diller’s decision to split IAC/InterActiveCorp into five parts says a lot about Mr. Diller’s restlessness. But it also shows the flaws in the strategy that he has been trying to pursue for a decade: building an Internet conglomerate.

title: The GPhone: So Open It Could Be Closed
abstract: Google’s Android software is meant to support cellphones of many shapes and sizes. It is wide open to any applications, but wireless carriers have the freedom to lock phones more tightly than even an iPhone.

title: Tools for the Chronically Obnoxious
abstract: Got some one really obnoxious on your gift list? They might not be content with just a cellphone jammer. Here are a few ideas.

title: Barry Diller Asks and Google Answers With Cash
abstract: As Barry Diller pares down IAC/InterActiveCorp, the remaining company’s coffers will get a lot fatter with a new $3.5 billion five-year advertising deal with Google.

title: One Other Little Dance
abstract: With Google’s introduction of a cellphone operating system, it adds another front of competition with Apple, even though Eric Schmidt, Google’s chief executive, serves on Apple’s board.

title: The Joy in Jamming
abstract: There is joy and considerable guilt in cellphone jamming.

title: Quit Yakking and Order Your Food
abstract: Jamming cellphones by businesses may become commonplace. How often have you been delayed in a line by a yakker?

title: Nostalgia About the News Is So Over
abstract: Tom Curley, the chief executive of the Associated Press, complained in a speech about nostalgic editors and portals that don’t pay for news content.

title: Which Advertiser Is on Your Friend List?
abstract: At a meeting called by the F.T.C., Esther Dyson wondered whether the way people are controlling information on social networks shouldn’t also apply to advertising.

title: The Secret to Raising the Value of Eyeballs
abstract: Mass advertising is dying, and targeted ads are one way that content companies are hoping to cover their costs.

title: No “Daily Show”? How a Writers’ Strike Would Affect Online Video
abstract: The prospect of a writers’ strike, and its eventual settlement, will set the terms for Internet video and may increase its audience.

title: MySpace Joins the Google OpenSocial Team
abstract: Breaking News: MySpace joins Google’s OpenSocial team.

title: Google’s OpenSocial Is Not a Facebook Killer
abstract: Google’s new OpenSocial initiative is nifty technology, but it’s not a product that in itself will cause any trouble for Facebook or MySpace.

title: The Great Facebook Team-Up?
abstract: Will OpenSocial make Facebook sweat?

title: Squeezing the VCs
abstract: Venture capitalists may have to pay more in taxes if a tax bill cleared by the House Ways and Means committee passes.

title: The Robot in the Newsroom
abstract: The New York Times redesigned technology Web page uses Blogrunner software that automates the discovery of relevant technology stories.

title: A Ten-Year-Old Mouse Helps Some Not-So-Cool Kids
abstract: Silicon Alley gets together to raise money in honor of the 10th birthday of Mouse, a group that helps schools use computers by teaching students to fix them.

title: A Cloudbook on the Horizon
abstract: The $299 eeePC is a lightweight portable computer that is meant for browsing Web sites and running Internet applications.

title: Facebook’s Rapid Stock Appreciation
abstract: The share price that Facebook has used for its employee stock options rose more than 30-fold between January 2006 and August 2007. It’s likely to experience another steep jump in value after Microsoft’s investment is factored in.

title: Still Waiting for Amazon’s Kindle
abstract: The Kindle, Amazon’s electronic book reader, was supposed to launch in October. E-book fans may have to wait a bit.

title: Opting-Out of Online Ads Can Make It Worse
abstract: Consumers who refuse to be targeted by opting out also tend to delete cookies from their computers. But those cookies often include the notice to ad companies that consumers did not want to be tracked.

title: Bye Bye Pampers: Google Is Fifth Most Valuable Company
abstract: With a market value of $217 billion, Google is now worth more than all but four companies in the United States.

title: Imeem Q&A: Competing in Music Through Community
abstract: Answering questions from Bits readers, Dalton Caldwell, the chief executive of Imeem, explains how the music-oriented social network plans to compete with MySpace, Facebook, and Apple.

title: Gordon Crovitz Gets Used to a Free WSJ.com
abstract: Just in time for the takeover of Dow Jones by News Corporation, the publisher of The Wall Street Journal says the company is rethinking its long-held belief that people should pay to read most of WSJ.com.

title: Bill Gates Has Joined Facebook! He Has Friends!
abstract: Bill Gates has a Facebook page, or at least humorist Jenny Lyn Bader imagines he does.

title: Industry Standard to Be Reincarnated as a Blog
abstract: IDG will bring back The Industry Standard, once a glossy Internet business magazine, as a blog.

title: The Back Door Into Facebook Ads
abstract: Although Microsoft has locked up banner ad space on the site, companies like AdBrite still see opportunities in other areas of Facebook.

title: Imeem Pioneers Free Music With Ads
abstract: Imeem, a music-oriented social network, now lets users listen to songs from three of the four major labels free. The fourth, Universal, is in talks to sign up for Imeem’s deal, which offers labels a share of its advertising revenue.

title: The Prescription for Health Care: Open Software or Forklifts?
abstract: How do you wire up all the doctors and hospitals to communicate with each other? Misys is has made its medical software open source.Athena Health has a proprietary system that has Web-based software and a warehouse full of paperwork.

title: Making Sense of Hulu
abstract: The News Corporation-NBC Universal video venture Hulu is a long-shot grab at the money from distributing video online. But the bloggers are wrong to compare it to YouTube.

title: Riding With Robots 2.0
abstract: Junior, a Volkswagen Passat controlled by a trunk full of computers, can think about a route, choose the best alternative, and even “cheat” on the rules a bit.

title: Whois May Be Whowas
abstract: A lack of agreement may end the whois database, which lists the owners of each Web domain.

title: Ask Questions of Dalton Caldwell, C.E.O. of Imeem
abstract: Dalton Caldwell founded Imeem as a chat and file sharing software service at the end of 2003. Today it is a rapidly growing social networking Web site.

title: A One-Click iPhone Jailbreak
abstract: A hacker group has released what it says is a one-click way to install unauthorized third-party applications on an iPhone or iPod Touch. You still can’t switch the iPhone to another wireless carrier.

title: Microsoft’s $30 Billion Vista Bump
abstract: Better-than-expected earnings, mainly from strong sales of Windows Vista, caused Microsoft shares to surge as much as 12 percent after hours, reaching a six-year high.

title: The $831 iPhone
abstract: Gene Munster, an analyst at Piper Jaffray, calculates that AT&T is paying Apple $18 a month for every iPhone activated.

title: The Greed of Facebook
abstract: In taking Microsoft’s money to hire a battalion of engineers to take on parts of Google, Mark Zuckerberg is embracing the 1999 rallying cry: Go big or go home.

title: Facebook’s Stock Options
abstract: Can Facebook lure the hottest talent with the prospective of becoming millionaires with stock options? Some people suggest the $15 billion valuation of the company will make it harder to get rich, really rich, there.

title: Deutsche Telekom Looks for Two-Tier Internet
abstract: Arguing that it is too expensive to deliver video to its home Internet users, Deutsche Telekom is preparing to charge a fee to companies that want to offer video and other high-bandwidth services, according to an industry newsletter.

title: Google Analyst Day (2): The Money
abstract: Google boasts that its huge advertising business has much more room to grow.

title: Google Analyst Day (1): Demos, but Nothing on Facebook
abstract: Some 300 analysts and investors are gathered at the Googleplex for its Analyst Day. No confirmation so far of rumors about Google and Microsoft bidding for a stake in Facebook.

title: Facebook to Wireless Companies: You Can Be Open, Too
abstract: Facebook co-founder Dustin Moskovitz called on the wireless industry to open their networks to independent developers. Carrier executives are unmoved.

title: Facebook’s Minority Report
abstract: Facebook is about to pick between offers from Google and Microsoft to buy a small share in the company at a huge value. This is great for Facebook, but for the potential investors, it is somewhere between irrelevant and insane.

title: Nokia Continues to Dominate Global Cellphone Market
abstract: In the third quarter, Nokia had nearly 40 percent of the global cellphone market. Samsung edged out Motorola for second place.

title: Google Analyst Day (3): Staying Friends With Facebook
abstract: Eric Schmidt, Google’s chief executive, told analysts and reporters he hoped to work with Facebook, even though it had taken an investment from Microsoft.

title: Microsoft Wins One in the War Against Google
abstract: Microsoft said it would invest $240 million in Facebook. The money will help Facebook challenge Google and by extension help Microsoft.

title: How Apple Can Keep Its Value
abstract: With a market value of $162 billion, Apple is now the most valuable computer maker in the world, and it is the fourth most valuable technology company, after Microsoft, Google and Cisco. It will have to battle all of them to stay on top of the tech world.

title: That Comcastic Voice and Data Network
abstract: Comcast endures technical errors during its defense of Internet blocking

title: Jerry Yang’s Musings on Opening Up Yahoo
abstract: Jerry Yang talks about opening up Yahoo to third party content and services

title: Rockies Rebound After Virtual Pummeling
abstract: The Colorado Rockies take two days to revive their ticket-sales Web site after it crashes from the weight of fans and potential scalpers.

title: Apple: $100 Million Spent on Potential iBricks
abstract: An interesting tidbit from the Apple earnings call: Of the 1.4 million iPhones sold so far, perhaps 250,000 of them were sold to people who wanted to unlock them from the AT&T network.

title: Black Friday Alert: Big Plasma Sets on Sale
abstract: This holiday season, prices for LCD sets will fall by less than 20 percent, while plasma set prices will be down 30 percent. Meanwhile low cost brands will take even more share from Sony and Samsung.

title: Comcast: We’re Delaying, Not Blocking, BitTorrent Traffic
abstract: Comcast tries to explain BitTorrent blocking reports. It manages the traffic for the average user and sometimes larger users of the pipes will find their content delayed, not blocked, the company says.

title: The Halo Over Xbox
abstract: Halo 3 sold 3.3 million copies in its first 12 days on the market, helping Microsoft’s Xbox 360 edge out the Nintendo Wii as the top-selling game console in September.

title: With Enough ‘Daily Show’ Clips, You’ve Got a Whole Program
abstract: You can watch all the jokes, fake news and interviews from last night’s “Daily Show” on its new Web site, but don’t call that a “full episode.” Viacom’s deal with cable companies prevents it from putting whole programs online.

title: What I Meant to Say Was Semantic Web
abstract: Radar Networks is introducing Twine.com, a service that uses semantic Web technology, sometimes called Web 3.0, to improve sharing information with friends and co-workers.

title: Listen Up: A New Kind of Spam
abstract: Get ready for a new kind of unsolicited junk e-mail: audio spam.

title: Google Promises Again to Swear Off Binge Hiring
abstract: After promising investors three months ago that it would rein in its rapid hiring, Google added 2,130 employees in the most recent quarter. It happened to offer jobs to 1,000 university graduates.

title: Brokering a Deal, Carefully, Between Malls and the Web
abstract: NearbyNow, a service to help malls put information on products and prices online, wants to draw customers from search engines. But it doesn’t want to drive mall shoppers back to Yahoo or Google.

title: The Fear Bubble
abstract: Prices for Internet companies are skyrocketing. But this bubble isn’t about the start-ups that can change the world; it is about established Internet companies afraid of Google, and what might be the next Google.

title: The Real History of WYSIWYG
abstract: A former Xerox hardware designer says his wife coined the term, which describes most modern software interfaces.

title: MySpace Needs Internal Not External Developers
abstract: MySpace will have new tools for people to develop programs for its site. MySpace has always been open, more so than Facebook. But it hasn’t done much to improve its own site.

title: Programmers Welcome for the iPhone … Next Year
abstract: Steve Jobs writes that Apple will release a software development kit for the iPhone in February, after it figures out how to keep hackers out.

title: Short Answers from Facebook’s Mark Zuckerberg
abstract: Facebook C.E.O. Mark Zuckerberg answers some questions at today’s Web 2.0 conference.

title: Falco Prepares Another Layoff: the AOL Brand
abstract: In the wake of massive layoffs, AOL’s chief executive wants to rebuild the company’s online business around a series of Web sites, few of which will use the AOL name.

title: Google’s Personal Health Record: Coming One of These Days
abstract: Marrissa Mayer talks, a little bit, about Google’s health initiative. It doesn’t feature a site with an “I’m feeling Yucky!” button.

title: Radio Nano Calling…Testing 1,2,3,4
abstract: “We don’t know what you’d do with a radio so small you couldn’t see it,” said researchers at the University of California at Irvine, but they are working on building one anyway.

title: Carlota Perez on the Web 2.0 Bubble
abstract: Carlota Perez, a historian, argues that bubbles occur throughout history — and can play a valuable role in picking winners from losers when there is new technology.

title: Facebook Settles With New York
abstract: New York state ends its investigation of Facebook, in exchange for faster response times on complaints. Other states are still pushing for more protection for young people.

title: Ubuntu Plans Eye Candy for Desktop Computers and Beyond
abstract: A new version of Linux offers 3D graphics to attract desktop computer users and eventually buyers of consumer electronics devices.

title: Apple Backs Down on Premium Prices for Unprotected Music
abstract: Apple dropped the price of music downloads not protected by copy restrictions from $1.29 to 99 cents, coming close to the price charged by Amazon.com and others.

title: For Yahoo, There’s No Place Like Home (Page)
abstract: Jerry Yang announced that Yahoo’s new strategy is the same as its old one: It wants to be your “starting point” for Web surfing and e-mail. He left out why people would start there.

title: Tuesday Is Layoff Day at AOL
abstract: When employees walk into AOL offices Tuesday morning, 1,200 of them will be quickly pulled aside by their managers.

title: AOL to Lay Off 20 Percent of Its Workers
abstract: Randy Falco, the chief executive of AOL, announced that the company would eliminate 2,000 of its 10,000 jobs.

title: Making Current TV More Current
abstract: Al Gore’s Current cable network upgrades its Web offering. The TV channel, however, has yet to hit home with the youth it wants to attract.

title: Bill Gates Presents the One (Really Big) Ringy Dingy
abstract: On Tuesday, Bill Gates will introduce new software to integrate communications by voice, video and instant messaging.

title: LinkedIn’s Dan Nye Responds to Your Questions
abstract: The chief executive of LinkedIn answers questions from users about possible new features and how to get more out of the features the site already has.

title: LinkedIn Plans to Open Up in a Closed Sort of Way
abstract: Dan Nye, LinkedIn’s chief executive, said the company will allow only outside applications that it approves, and it is interested in a share of the revenue of companies that use its platform. No food fights need apply.

title: For BEA, Years of Rumors Become Reality
abstract: When Oracle offered $6.7 billion for BEA Systems on Friday, one of the Street’s longest-running rumors finally turned into fact.

title: Ask Questions of Dan Nye, C.E.O. of LinkedIn
abstract: The future of social networking? Competing with Facebook? All those e-mails from people wanting you in their network? Ask your question for Dan Nye, the C.E.O. of LinkedIn, in the comments to this post.

title: Shawn Fanning’s Snocap Prepares for Fire Sale
abstract: Snocap, a service started by Shawn Fanning, the Napster founder, that was meant to help music companies profit from file-trading systems, has laid off 60 percent of its staff and is preparing for a sale.

title: Plasma TVs: The SUVs of the Living Room
abstract: When the Australian government wanted to create a six-star system to rate the energy efficiency of television sets, it found that most of the big plasma sets wouldn’t meet its minimum requirements.

title: Senator Schumer to Credit Agencies: Make It Easier to Freeze Credit
abstract: In a letter, Senator Charles E. Schumer asks the credit agencies to eliminate fees for people who need to freeze access to their credit records in order to prevent identity theft. If they don’t, he said he would introduce legislation to force their hand.

title: Google, Mozilla and the Open-Source Phone
abstract: The rise of open-source cellphone software will challenge wireless handset makers and carriers.

title: The Luddite in the Googleplex
abstract: Speaking to the especially wired group of executives and politicians at Google’s Zeitgeist conference, Yves Chouinard, the founder of the Patagonia outdoor clothing maker, said he has never used a keyboard and that technology tends to homogenize culture.

title: Google Gives Some Hints About Social Network Plan
abstract: Eric Schmidt, the chief executive of Google, said the company plans to use the social information implicit in Gmail and its other services to improve its search engine.

title: Viral Videos Still Rule at Metacafe
abstract: As other video sites turn to professional and semi-pro programs to create environments that appeal to advertisers, Metacafe has attracted a huge audience with a menu devoted to short, funny, sexy and stupid clips.

title: One Reason We Need a Google Phone: Free GPS
abstract: Consumers spent $60 million in the second quarter to use navigation features built into their cellphones. Google could offer this feature free.

title: The Future of Journalism Is Stuck in the Lincoln Tunnel
abstract: One person who isn’t on the program for Wednesday’s Network Journalism Summit but should be is Joshua Crandall, the founder of Clever Commute, a service through which bus and train riders alert each other to delays.

title: Free the Avatars
abstract: Virtual worlds may be freewheeling environments where cyber-behavior is unconstrained by many terrestrial mores. But they are also gated communities, and the gates keep the digital denizens locked inside.

title: Lawyer Sues Over iPhone’s Little White List
abstract: A federal suit claims Apple’s restrictions on the iPhone violate antitrust law and its recent software update is illegal trespass.

title: Google Founders Pick Up Another Big Plane
abstract: Google’s billionaire founders, owners of a Boeing 767 that has been the talk of Silicon Valley, are apparently adding another unusually large private jet to their fleet: a Boeing 757.

title: Hackers Break Out of the iPhone (but Not for Long?)
abstract: The iPhone can be opened for unofficial applications, but Apple appears to be preparing to promote more officially sanctioned applications.

title: The Macrocompany (Google) Buys Into Microblogging (Jaiku)
abstract: Despite the frenzy among some in Silicon Valley for Twitter, it’s hard to see that what has become known as microblogging will thrive on stand-alone services.

title: Is TiVo’s Comeback the Real Deal?
abstract: TiVo will bring RealNetworks’ Rhapsody music service to its customers’ boxes as part of its plan to turn TiVo boxes into Internet media hubs.

title: Google Shares Shoot Past $600
abstract: Why are the company’s shares still climbing? Analysts have a number of theories.

title: What GPhone?
abstract: Google is getting into the phone software business, competing with Microsoft, rather than the cellphone business, competing with Apple, Nokia and the rest.

title: Breaking Up Is Too Hard for Yahoo to Do
abstract: A Sanford C. Bernstein analyst suggests that Yahoo is worth more split into pieces than it is now. That’s not going to happen, so the company may end up being a piece of something bigger yet.

title: Credit Freezes Spread but Thawing Your Report Is Still Difficult
abstract: The three major credit agencies are rolling out credit freezes nationwide, but they could make it much easier for consumers.

title: Does This Webcam Make Me Look Fat?
abstract: The latest variation in dating is speed dating combined with Webcasts. One can bet this is going to end up misused.

title: Will Facebook’s Developers Defect to Other Platforms?
abstract: Will Facebook’s zealous developers migrate when rival social networks introduce their own open platforms?

title: Is That You I Saw at the Bus Stop…in Adelaide?
abstract: An issue about who has rights to use a picture of a 15-year-old girl in an advertisement shows that what is on a billboard in Australia might embarrass someone in Texas.

title: NBC’s Zucker Calls for Allies in Copyright Battle
abstract: NBC’s chief executive calls for phone companies and universities and others to join in a crusade to stop piracy. But there are a number of reason this strategy maight not bring the results he seeks.

title: The Pin-On Video Screen
abstract: My iButton is a video player set in a plastic frame that you can pin on your clothes.

title: Your Moment of Facebook Zen
abstract: Is your Facebook page getting a little cluttered because you just can’t stop adding new applications? Perhaps you need some Dramatic Whitespace.

title: A Day of Robots, Rocket Cycles and Lasers
abstract: Gadgetoff was the festival of the future that never was.

title: Microsoft Sings a New Zune
abstract: It’s hard to imagine anyone reading about the latest Zune models from Microsoft and putting them at the top of their Christmas wish list.

title: My iBrick Part 1: The Meltdown
abstract: 6:41 a.m.: We are in the throes of trying to get out of the house, when my 14-year-old daughter says, “There’s something wrong with my phone.”

title: My iBrick Part 2: The Fix
abstract: A software update. A visit to an Apple Store. One attempt to fix it fails. The saga continues.

title: Bubblewatch: The Industry Standard Is Coming Back
abstract: Media company IDG is looking for an editor to help a revived Industry Standard, the erstwhile technology trade publication.

title: AT&T Welcomes Programmers for All Phones Except the iPhone
abstract: Apple says it won’t allow independent programs on the iPhone to protect AT&T’s network. But AT&T encourages third-party applications for all of its other phones.

title: Orson Welles, Meet Dexter
abstract: Showtime’s viral campaign for the show “Dexter” is done so well it is fooling people into thinking they are stalked by a serial killer. Is it smart marketing or just a cruel hoax?

title: Another Day, Another RFID Trial
abstract: Privacy advocates have been increasingly worried about how the use of radio identification tags on merchandise could leave consumers vulnerable to government and industry spying on their purchasing habits and behavior.

title: Do We Need an Internet TV Network?
abstract: Web TV network Joost is opening its service to the online public. Will anyone want to watch? The biggest challenge for the London-based company: convincing people to put their Web browsing on hold, lean back in their computer desk chairs and tune in.

title: EBay’s $4 Billion Lesson in the Value of Hype
abstract: Skype was adding 150,000 new users a day when eBay bought it two years ago, figuring the money would follow. It didn’t — at least not enough.

title: Hackers Get their iPhones (Back)
abstract: Hackers have been able to restore at least some functions on iPhones that had been disabled by last week’s Apple update.

title: More on Apple’s Latest Product, the iBrick
abstract: A few iPhone owners found that Apple stores will help revive phones disabled by yesterday’s software update. But others still have iBricks.

title: Navigating to Nowhere on the iPhone
abstract: In less than two weeks, people downloaded 80,000 copies of the Navizon location software for the iPhone. It’s now useless after Apple’s phone software upgrade.

title: Inside the Brain of a Gadget Compulsive
abstract: As he prepared for the onslaught of submarines, a homemade rail gun, a few billionaires and a grounded blimp, Dan Dubno took time Thursday to get his brain scanned.

title: Yahoo’s V.P. Huddle and Music Cuts
abstract: There may not be major changes afoot at the company, but the entertainment division gets a shakeup.

title: Image and Reality in the Search Wars
abstract: Microsoft and Yahoo have improved their search engines. But it will take both technology and marketing to convince Google users to switch.

title: Shopping in Shanghai, From Your PC at Home
abstract: A new site, Shangby, allows Western shoppers to buy the comparatively cheaper items from stores in Shanghai, China.

title: Microsoft Video Crossing Platforms
abstract: Microsoft is expected to announce a new Internet T. system that works on televisions and computers at the Digital Life Conference today.

title: The Intel Ministry of Education
abstract: Intel announced a new initiative to rapidly broaden the reach of its program, Intel Teach. The Intel effort focuses on training teachers around the world to use personal computers as a tool in classrooms.

title: Steve Jobs Girds for the Long iPhone War
abstract: After a software update, iPhones that have been modified do, as Apple warned, turn into bricks. The company must prepare for a long, nasty fight with its own customers.

title: Warning: Wait to Hack the iPhone
abstract: A warning about those third-party software applications for the iPhone.

title: Bargaining Down Your Internet Bill
abstract: It may be time to renegotiate your telephone service.

title: Samsung’s Nanotech Washer Must Follow Bug-Spray Rules
abstract: The Environmental Protection Agency will evaluate a washing machine made by Samsung under pesticide rules because it generates and mixes silver ions into loads of laundry to kill bacteria and other microbes.

title: Sticky Old People (Redux)
abstract: Waterfront Media raises $25 million to expand its health and fitness Web business, another example of money flowing into sites that target older users.

title: What’s in Google’s Name?
abstract: One man sues Google because his Social Security number turned upside down and scrambled spells the name Google. Another argues Google stole its name from the Gogo tribe of Tanzania. There may be 1 followed by 100 zeros more allegations.

title: Google’s Washington Hazing for Its DoubleClick Deal
abstract: A Senate panel will look at Google’s proposed acquisition of DoubleClick on Thursday. After a lot of discussion about privacy, the consensus seems to be that the deal will be approved this fall.

title: M.I.A.: ‘Veterans of the War Against Microsoft’
abstract: Pondering the meaning of a mysterious sign in Microsoft’s New York offices.

title: Amazon Launches a Music Store, Not a Service
abstract: Amazon waited to offer digital music until it could sell unrestricted MP3 files, rather than songs with digital rights management. It may force Apple to compete on price and terms.

title: The Larger Challenge (and Opportunity) for One Laptop Per Child
abstract: The One Laptop program faces more challenges than uninterested world leaders.

title: New Ideas in Thin Computing – I
abstract: Teradici is attacking the thin-client computing market with a customized chip.

title: New Ideas in Thin Computing – II
abstract: NComputing: the $70 computer for schools and offices?

title: Walmart.com to Customers: Stop Calling
abstract: When it comes to customer service, who needs a human touch? Not Wal-Mart’s online customers, apparently.

title: New Ideas in Thin Computing – III
abstract: Another alternative to thin computing is embedding the PC’s operating system on a chip.

title: New York State Investigates Facebook
abstract: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo is asking for information on how the site handles complaints regarding the inappropriate solicitation of under-age users.

title: The Captive Cell Phone Tappers
abstract: New mobile ad services from Google, MySpace and others show that cellphone advertising is coming, but slowly.

title: History Lesson: A Facebook Stake May Be Worth Little to Microsoft
abstract: Facebook would be lucky to take $500 million from Microsoft for a 5 percent stake. But Microsoft’s history of cable investments may dissuade it from such a deal.

title: Google’s New Highs
abstract: What’s driving GOOG higher. Could it be nothing?

title: Google’s Cables Make Unnecessary Waves
abstract: Google has long considered becoming part owner of undersea cables.

title: Has Google Plans to Lay a Pacific Cable?
abstract: A report says Google is putting together a group to lay a data cable under the Pacific to reduce costs and increase capacity.

title: One Anti-Piracy System to Rule Them All
abstract: Digital fingerprinting company Vobile is winning the movie industry’s tests of anti-piracy technology.

title: Is Zillow Immune From a Housing Crash?
abstract: So what’s frothier: the stock market in 1999, the real estate market six months ago, or the valuation of Zillow?

title: Techcrunch Founder Shares His Pulpit
abstract: Michael Arrington hires a co-editor of his tech site.

title: Why Portals Are So Over at AOL
abstract: The problem is the portal.

title: Rather Charges That CBS Wanted to 'Curry Favor' With White House
abstract: The television industry will be poring over the $70 million lawsuit filed today by Dan Rather. The 32-page filing lists 123 information items and seven causes of action and, in its conclusion, explicitly claims that CBS was motivated by political considerations:

title: ESPN Deportes Makes Its Move
abstract: ESPN Deportes, the Spanish language version of the sports programming powerhouse, is moving off Time Warner Cable's "en Espanol" tier and onto the digital basic channel line-up favored by viewers and advertisers.

title: Will 'Kid Nation' Flunk Its First Test?
abstract: We're a few hours away from the premiere of "Kid Nation," the most talked-about new show of the fall season.

title: NBC Brings the Most Popular Word to TV Downloads: Free
abstract: NBC is betting that free trumps fee with downloads of its prime-time shows.

title: The Gated Social Network
abstract: New social networks are building businesses based on exclusivity and limiting the number of users.

title: Hollywood Will Let You Copy Movies, Sort Of
abstract: A vote Wednesday changedthe legal agreement that governs the copy-protection system used on DVDs. Now people can burn DVDs at home.

title: The Nobel Prize That Wasn’t
abstract: Michael Nobel, Alfred Nobel’s great grand nephew, offered to introduce a new Nobel Prize for alternative energy at a Nanotechnology conference.

title: The Cloud Over the British iPhone
abstract: Apple will offer the iPhone in Britain with free access to 7,500 WiFi hot spots to compensate for a weak data network.

title: Neutron Randy Vaporizes AOL
abstract: With management firings, layoffs and strategy changes Randy Falco may have a plan, but it appears he is forging a new company from scratch.

title: They Lasted Longer Than Airline Meals Did
abstract: The death of the paper airline ticket is finally at hand.

title: Virgin America Hunts Its Bugs
abstract: Virgin America talks about bugs and upgrades to its in-flight entertainment system

title: The Bugs in Virgin America’s New High-Tech Flights
abstract: The airplane crash was only the in-flight entertainment system, but it was still unsettling.

title: Europe’s Latest Blow to Microsoft
abstract: The rejection of Microsoft’s appeal of its antitrust case in Europe means the company will face restrictions when it seeks to add new features to Windows. It will have a harder time keeping secrets too.

title: Losing Money on the iPhone and Making It Up on Volume
abstract: Apple is likely to make so much money from its cut of iPhone usage fees that it can sell the product at a loss and still make money.

title: Powerset to Skeptics: Try Us
abstract: Powerset opens the kimono, a bit, hoping to turn skeptics into believers

title: The iPhone Heads to Europe; Euros Head to Cupertino
abstract: Apple’s reportedly will announce deals to sell the iPhone in Europe this week. Carriers O2, Orange and T-Mobile are said to be giving huge portions of the usage fees back to Apple.

title: Yahoo Mash: The Social Network for Graffiti Lovers
abstract: Yahoo has started an invitation-only preview of a new social networking site, Yahoo Mash. It is quite an homage to Facebook, but it adds one significant new wrinkle: users can edit each other’s profiles, redecorating, changing information, and adding features.
